resources.string: The College of Arts and Sciences building is the main hub for all things Arts. It is the main building used for Game Design students, one of the most rapidly-growing majors here at Quinnipiac. It hosts many things like general classrooms, the advising commons for students in the College of Arts and Sciences, and a state-of-the-art computer lab in the basement, which is the main room for all Game Design classes. This lab has multiple computers which can run high-quality programs like Unity, Z-Brush, Adobe Photoshop, and more.

The Communications, Computing and Engineering building, otherwise known as CCE, is the hub for all Computer Science, Engineering, and Communications students. It holds the main Auditorium room, CCE101, which is used for a variety of different events, like seminars, celebrations, and training for RA’s. This building has 3 levels. The main level is used for film and media students, which is home to the communications students. The bottom floor has a host of the reservable study rooms, engineering classrooms, and computer labs. The top floor has standard-style classrooms used for all students.
Fun Fact: CCE was originally planned to be a library for Law Students, but was eventually renovated to be made with classrooms for all students.

This building is the main building used for visitors who are interested in coming to Quinnipiac, as well as the main office for the Undergraduate Admissions and financial aid. This building is also home to many classes, especially for Nursing students, as well as other general classes.

The Lender School of Business is the go-to building for all Business, Finance, and Economics majors. It is home to many collaborative classrooms, reservable study rooms, and the Financial Technology Center. This room has multiple Bloomberg Terminals, a student-led portfolio, and multiple connecting study rooms, with multiple stock market tickers.
This building, connected to the Carl Hansen Student Center, which serves as a hub for all types of classes with many labs, general classrooms, and offices for faculty members.

The Arnold Bernhard Library is Quinnipiac’s most iconic building on campus. Its infamous clock tower skies over the whole quad, and is the main centerpiece for graduations. This two-story building has multiple open spaces for studying for all students. It also has multiple reservable study rooms for more collaborative, or more silent, work. It is also home to the Registrar, Bursar, Learning Commons, Student Administrative Services, Information Services, and the Technology Center. It is mainly open from 8am-12am, but during midterms and finals week, the library stays open as late as 2am.
Creators: Cole Davignon (left) and Brooks Jackson (right)

Important Phone Numbers
Public Safety: (203) 582-6200 
Student Health Services: (203) 407-4050

Cole and Brooks are both Bachelor’s of Computer Science majors, while being in the 3+1 Cybersecurity Master’s program. They both have interests in Game Design, in which they both have classes together in the Game Design program.

Our plan with this project is to make the QU experience more interactive and helpful.​ Our main goal of this project was to help incoming students understand our campus more​, since there can be some confusing parts. It is hard to soak it all in. We believed that if we had this app as incoming Bobcats, it would have answered so many questions for us, especially in the housing selection time period. Sometimes, we felt as if the upperclassmen dorms were foreign and we did not know which was which. We also believed this app could be helpful for international students interested, but cannot travel far. We believe that this app can change the way we see our campus, even without coming for a tour. We hoped to further expand this in the future, maybe adding York Hill information as well​! The Quinnipiac Tracker App can help so many people; incoming students, current students, staff, faculty, and even parents!

One of the many First-Year housing options. It is home to quad-style dorms, with community bathrooms in each wing. It hosts many lobbies with large laundry rooms, and a common kitchen area. Each dorm holds 4 students with lofted beds, a desk, a closet, and carpeted floors. This building is very infamous for the long wooden bridge that all students walk on, as it is in one of the prettiest parts of campus. Commons is very heavily used for traffic control to and from the CAS building.

This string of dorms are 3 buildings that make up The Complex. These buildings being Sahlin, Bakke, and Founders, are exact copies of each other. These recently renovated Sophomore dorms have a very modern and unique feel. It has its own kitchen, with its own fridge, stove, oven, and even a kitchen island! This apartment holds 4 students, containing 2 single dorms and a double. The room is provided with furniture for both the common space and the kitchen island seating.

This is one of the main buildings for First-Years. The most classic dorm style; holds 2 residents, with community bathrooms on each floor, separated by gender. Its counterpart, Irma, has the same layout, style, and dorm spaces.

One of the most popular choices of the Sophomore dorms. These dorms have the most perks; AC, kitchen, fridge, common room provided with some furniture, a bathroom, and even a balcony, which overlooks the whole Bobcat Way. These dorms hold 3 doubles with the 7 buildings being separated by 10’s-30’s and then 40’s to 70’s.

This is one of the main buildings for First-Years. The most classic dorm style; holds 2 residents, with community bathrooms on each floor, separated by gender. Its counterpart, Dana, has the same layout, style, and dorm spaces.

One of the three buildings that make up the Suites, the other two being Perlroth and Troup. This Sophomore building is a mall-style building that has 20 suites inside. Its gigantic common mall has multiple chairs, tables, and stools to get homework done or to relax in. It is a very busy place at night time for all students, and in the hot days of May. The mall has a common kitchen with a stove, oven, and common fridge. The suites hold mainly 8 residents, 4 doubles, and have their own common room with provided furniture, bathroom, and even AC.

Ledges is a First-Year Quad-Style Residence Hall, located right by Hogan Parking Lot and our baseball fields. It hosts many lounges that could be used for study rooms, general common rooms, or places to host events for RA’s.\nFun Fact: At one point, the study rooms on each floor were used for dorms! Each of these rooms hosted 8 people in one room, with a large open-space.

Mountainview is the most unique of all of the First-Year dorms. It is a hotel-esque building with suite-style rooms that have 4 doubles, a bathroom in each suite, and a spacious common room that is provided with furniture. Each bathroom has 2 sinks, 2 toilets, and 2 showers. It also has 2 common kitchens that can be used by anyone. This dorm is located right behind Ledges and close to the Hogan Lot.

One of the three buildings that make up the Suites, the other two being Larson and Troup. This Sophomore building is a mall-style building that has 20 suites inside. Its gigantic common mall has multiple chairs, tables, and stools to get homework done or to relax in. It is a very busy place at night time for all students, and in the hot days of May. The mall has a common kitchen with a stove, oven, and common fridge. The suites hold mainly 8 residents, 4 doubles, and have their own common room with provided furniture, bathroom, and even AC.

The Bobcat Den, also known as the Rat, is a very popular spot for all students on main campus. The Rat has a multitude of options, such as a Chipotle-style mexican spot, mobile order all-day breakfast and grill, and a grinder shop. In the Rat is also a multitude of different snacks, drinks, and candies that can serve as groceries for some students. The Rat is located right on Bobcat Way, near the infamous Bobcat Statue, and right behind the Residential Life Office. It is open very late every day, making it a popular spot for midnight snacks.

The main cafeteria on campus. This building is connected to Tator hall, and the Buckman Theater. This is located in the center of campus, right on the quad by the library. This dining hall has many restaurant locations which are open every day. Within the cafeteria there is a burger spot, pizza, sandwiches, all-day breakfast, and gluten-free choices. The main restaurant, called Create Global, is cuisine that changes every day. The food can range from Italian to Mexican to Chinese. One of the most popular days is Saturday evening, where they serve the incredibly popular General Tso’s Chicken.

One of the three buildings that make up the Suites, the other two being Larson and Perlroth. This Sophomore building is a mall-style building that has 20 suites inside. Its gigantic common mall has multiple chairs, tables, and stools to get homework done or to relax in. It is a very busy place at night time for all students, and in the hot days of May. The mall has a common kitchen with a stove, oven, and common fridge. The suites hold mainly 8 residents, 4 doubles, and have their own common room with provided furniture, bathroom, and even AC.

A popular choice for Sophomore residents. Village is quite a unique style, since there are 28 separated buildings that are split up into 2 different styles; Old Village and New Village. Both buildings hold 3 doubles that have their own fairly large common rooms, and a bathroom. Each building has 4 suites, 2 of which have an upstairs style that have much taller ceilings than the other 2 suites with low ceilings. Old Village is not as modern as New, but still has its perks since those buildings are closer to Bobcat Way than the rest of the dorms. New Village has the same perks as Old Village and has the same amenities, but no furniture is provided, unlike Old Village. New Village however has bigger rooms, common rooms, and bathrooms.
Fun Fact: Cole is an RA in New Village, and he loves it! Additionally, Brooks, one of the app’s creators, lives in Village too!
